fields.description:
The Documentation is clear informing that the plan Clone does not depend on the Clone Permission only but also on the Global Permission to Create Plans.

However, the Plan Permissions UI still allow Admins to add Clone permission even if the Creation permission is was not granted. In this case, Clones would not work, but the UI should make this clear, by disabling the Clone permission checkbox.
fields.summary: Enable Clone permission checkbox only if the user has Global Permission to Create plans
Would be useful if the dropbox items are sorted when selecting logs to view

fields.description: Raised from BSP-4193. We have 5-6MB/s on local transfers. That's waaay lower than it should be. I've tested a fix that should improve it to ~80MB/s on local/LAN transfers. We can probably expect ~5x increase on remote transfers.

fields.description:
See http://studio.atlassian.com/browse/STRM-944 for backstory.

The only change we need to make to Bamboo proper to make everything work with Activity Streams 4 is to turn off requests to remote servers. In Streams 3.x and prior, that functionality existed in a separate plugin, so the param wasn't required. Now, local=true needs to be specified else you'll receive content from applinked atlassian instances.
fields.summary: Add local=true query param to Recent Builds url so that remote content doesn't get loaded

fields.description:
Bamboo 3.0 promised to improve the GUI a lot. As I was missing many things after upgrading to 2.7 due to the new stages, I read that Bamboo 3.0 will address these things. So I waited for Bamboo 3.0.

Now I see that in deed it became much better, but I'm still missing some important things, not really missing them they are still there, but to far away.

1) before in the Plan Summary the <Project Key>-<Plan Key> was visible in the GUI somewhere. Yes I know it is still there, in the URL, but was quite handy to see it on the overveiw page(s) too. Now we only see the "Plan Name". I could duplicate the infos we have coded into the "Plan Key" to the "Plan name", but our decision was to put some of the infos about plans into the "Plan Key", and some other infos into the "Plan Name". Now I have to either change (and duplicate infos) into the Plan Name, or live with the fact that it is very hard to find the infos we had before. Changing ~100 plans is not a good idea, but duplicating infos is even worse, this may lead to inconsistent states when changing plans.

2) The "Build Result Summary"

Again I'm speaking of a plan that only has one "Default Job". Here I'm missing the "Error Summary" section (most important is the "full build log" download link). If the build does not create test results this sections seems to be available (yes it should be there similar like this), but as soon as we have tests results and some tests fail this part disappears. 

As soon as something goes wrong I would like to see the whole build log easily. I would not need the stderr output, this one often does not catch the real problems, but it would be very helpfull to get a direct link to the full build log.

You may argue it is only one click away (goto the default job and scroll down until you find it). Thats true, but in real live I first scroll down and see it is not here, than I click to the default job and don't see it, then I scroll down there and yes I'll find it.

Me as somebody using Bamboo very often may get used to this, but it costs me lots of time to teach others to be as patient as I have to be.

3) Not that important, but why did you change the colors for the "run" "stop" icons in the Dashboard/All Plans  View (those icons at the very right of each plan entry). Before the run icon was green and the stop icon was red. Now bot of them have the same black color. For elder peoples it is not that simple to see the difference between the triangle icon and the square. So I would vote for the old colors here again. Else the new icons look nice :-)
fields.summary: Please bring back some GUI feautres we had befoe Bamboo 2.7

fields.description:
See [BSP-4172|https://support.atlassian.com/browse/BSP-4172], [BSP-4188|https://support.atlassian.com/browse/BSP-4188], BAM-8252.

Trying to use {{https://github.com/crossroads/fat_free_crm.git}} causes git plugin to throw "Missing unknown {rev}" exceptions. That repository contains [submodules|http://book.git-scm.com/5_submodules.html]. Apparently JGit doesn't support them yet:
* http://dev.eclipse.org/mhonarc/lists/jgit-dev/msg00500.html
* https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=314853
* http://egit.eclipse.org/r/#change,1083

(I've tried to clone above repository using plain org.eclipse.jgit.pgm in version 0.11.3 but it failed with the similar symptoms. Eclipse's egit fails with the same exception)
fields.summary: Git Repository should support submodules

fields.description:
Hi there folk!

So I'm looking at the Crowd and Bamboo integration guide here:
http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD010/3.2.2+Integrating+Crowd+with+Atlassian+Bamboo

And there are two steps they suggest you take. Now -- in the atlassian-user.xml file, it more or less says only to comment out the hibernate line, and uncomment <crowd key="crowd" name="Crowd Repository"/>

Doing only these steps seems to work fine. I'm assuming I would still have to make the mod to the seraph config if I wanted SSO, but is the first step in the docs still true or is what it says in atlassian-user.xml true? 

Things seem to be running just fine but I'm just trying to clarify and perhaps suggest a documentation update. =)
fields.summary: Bamboo 3.0 and Crowd integration docs -- are they still valid?

fields.description:
*Steps to reproduce:*
# Add a Bamboo server in JIRA
# Navigate to the Gadget directory, noticed that there are 4 Bamboo gadgets namely 'Bamboo Charts', 'Bamboo Plan Summary Chart', 'Bamboo Plans' and 'Clover Coverage'. See [screenshot|^BambooGadget.png]
# Shut down Bamboo server
# Restart JIRA
# From the JIRA log, this is shown:
{noformat}
2011-02-22 18:24:39,452 main WARN      [plugin.ext.bamboo.BambooServerManagerImpl] Failed to connect to http://localhost:8085/rest/gadgets/1.0/g/com.atlassian.bamboo.gadgets/charts/bambooCharts.xmlConnection refused
2011-02-22 18:24:39,453 main WARN      [plugin.ext.bamboo.BambooServerManagerImpl] Gadget http://localhost:8085/rest/gadgets/1.0/g/com.atlassian.bamboo.gadgets/charts/bambooCharts.xml is unavailable.  Gadget was not added to the gadget browser.
2011-02-22 18:24:39,454 main WARN      [plugin.ext.bamboo.BambooServerManagerImpl] Failed to connect to http://localhost:8085/rest/gadgets/1.0/g/com.atlassian.bamboo.gadgets/status/planStatus.xmlConnection refused
2011-02-22 18:24:39,454 main WARN      [plugin.ext.bamboo.BambooServerManagerImpl] Gadget http://localhost:8085/rest/gadgets/1.0/g/com.atlassian.bamboo.gadgets/status/planStatus.xml is unavailable.  Gadget was not added to the gadget browser.
2011-02-22 18:24:39,455 main WARN      [plugin.ext.bamboo.BambooServerManagerImpl] Failed to connect to http://localhost:8085/rest/gadgets/1.0/g/com.atlassian.bamboo.gadgets/charts/planSummaryChart.xmlConnection refused
2011-02-22 18:24:39,455 main WARN      [plugin.ext.bamboo.BambooServerManagerImpl] Gadget http://localhost:8085/rest/gadgets/1.0/g/com.atlassian.bamboo.gadgets/charts/planSummaryChart.xml is unavailable.  Gadget was not added to the gadget browser.
2011-02-22 18:24:39,456 main WARN      [plugin.ext.bamboo.BambooServerManagerImpl] Failed to connect to http://localhost:8085/rest/gadgets/1.0/g/com.atlassian.bamboo.gadgets/status/cloverCoverage.xmlConnection refused
2011-02-22 18:24:39,456 main WARN      [plugin.ext.bamboo.BambooServerManagerImpl] Gadget http://localhost:8085/rest/gadgets/1.0/g/com.atlassian.bamboo.gadgets/status/cloverCoverage.xml is unavailable.  Gadget was not added to the gadget browser.
{noformat}

It shows that JIRA was not able to connect to the Bamboo server. This is true. However, those gadgets will be removed from the gadget directory at the same time.

*Workaround:*

Option 1: Startup Bamboo server first, then only startup JIRA
Option 2: Update the Bamboo Server without changing anything (_Administration -> Global Settings -> Bamboo Servers_)
fields.summary: JIRA Bamboo Gadgets will be Removed from the Directory when Bamboo server is down and after restarting JIRA server

fields.description:
Don't take me wrong, Bamboo 3.0 is the closest to Hudson we've had so far (in terms of flexibility). I was almost able to duplicate a multi stage work from Hudson.

My issue is the way things are "shared". First each job has a copy of the repository, there's no way to disabling checking out from the repository. In my case I have 5 jobs in my plan meaning I have 5 copies of the repository that needs to be updated. Meaning 5 times adding the time of updating the repository and 5 times the disk space consumption on disk.

The second issue id that "shared" artifacts are not shared, just copied and pasted. I expected sharing to be exactly that, reuse the artifact. I think that all jobs within the same plan should be ran on the same place, using one repository copy instead of one per job, is not efficient in my opinion.

The stage concept is great but the way it is implemented might not be the best. Stages/Jobs should be working on the same working directory not copies of them. Probably adding an option in the job to revert the repository would be equivalent to the clean repository copy each job uses now with the same resuts and less overhead.
fields.summary: Really share instead of copy and paste

fields.description:
From JSP-72696 & BAM-2867

{quote}
    I protest at this being pushed off as a "new feature request". To me, it is clearly a broken function of an existing feature. If my facts are wrong please correct them:

       1. Jira allows the configuration of multiple bamboo servers, with individual jira project keys configured for each separate server. That's what we want - we just expect it to work.
       2. The (http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Integrating+Bamboo+with+JIRA) page clearly says: "You can configure multiple Bamboo servers, but only one server can be associated to one JIRA project at a time". We're fine with the limitation. But the fact that it says "you can configure..." tells me this is a supported function. Unless I need to assume that statements like that don't mean "...and you can actually expect it to function" but instead mean "... but it won't actually do anything because we haven't implemented that 'feature' yet".
       3. The bamboo dashboard gadgets have similar comments and appear to support multiple bamboo servers
       4. When we were originally evaluating having a 2nd bamboo instance we checked with Atlassian and they said that it would work. I unfortunately don't have the contact name anymore (it was over a year ago).
       5. Most of this integration actually works, with the same behavior on the project build pages and on issue build tabs:
             1. The name, link, and URL is correct for build server "title" at the top of the page/tab.
             2. The build information is correct in the detail (it's looking at the correct bamboo server for the info)
       6. The only piece that's wrong is the actual URL to the build is being build with the prefix of the wrong bamboo server - the path and file of the URL is correct!
       7. BTW: I'm also 99% certain this used to work, but I can't "prove it". We tested this integration extensively when we added the second bamboo server - I'm certain those links were tested and worked before. We're not sure precisely when, since there was a period of months between our testing and the actual production use of it.
{quote}
fields.summary: URL in JIRA Issues tab is not being updated correctly

fields.description:
We use dependencies as a work-around for not having multiple build triggers. 

(1)

In this case there is no need for a "builder" script. Since Bamboo requires one, we run a bogus shell command like 'echo'. That is a minor problem but it's an annoyance. If Bamboo will not support multiple build triggers, we need the builder to be optional.

(2)

There is no need to pull source. Bamboo requires source repository info to be provided. So we pull in a small part of our subversion repo for no reason other than to make Bamboo happy.

There should be separate tabs for "Source Repository" and "Triggers." I understand they are related, but triggers should not require a source repository depending on the type of trigger desired.
fields.summary: Changes needed for workaround for lack of multiple triggers

fields.description: It would be very handy to be able to start a build immediately even if the "quiet period" detection functionality thinks the should be delayed. It's annoying and dangerous to change a build plan to temporarily override the detection.
fields.summary: A way to override the "quiet period" delay

fields.description: Our build process writes status to STDOUT, such as the current script that is executing. Sometimes one of our scripts hangs. We can't tell which script is hanging via the Bamboo UI because the Activity tab appears to buffer output. The last line written to STDOUT is critical. We'd rather not try to outsmart Bamboo by writing a lot of bogus lines to STDOUT.
fields.summary: STDOUT and STDERR buffering is very annoying

fields.summary: Git repository shoudn't contain '.git/shallow' file if it's not a shallow repository

fields.description: Recently on tardigrade the plan using IDEA git repository has swollen up to 12GB. I couldn't investigate closely as we needed recover that 12GB disk space, but I think it was the {{.git/pack}} directory which was full of index/pack files. This could be due to shallow clone strategy, this could be normal behavior - I don't know. Anyway the clean IDEA repository ({{git://git.jetbrains.org/idea/community.git}}) takes no more than 2GB disk space, so it might be worth investigating this issue.
fields.summary: Git working directory repository shouldn't use up disk space too much.

fields.description:
Recently we switched in Mercurial strategy from "hg clone" to "hg init ; hg pull" (see BAM-7632).
However this increased the time of copying (cloning/pulling) cache repository into workdir directory of an agent. This action should be instant, as HG has facilities to do fast local clones.
fields.summary: Mercurial: Cloning from cache to working directory should be instant (performance)

fields.description:
Currently the "non-interactive" option is always appended to the Grails command.

This setting should be optional.

Currently, if the "non-interactive" is appended to the end of a "grails schema-export", the file name generated will be "non-interactive"

A workaround would be to add the following command to the Grails Builder so that Bamboo can identify that it already exists and don't append it.
{code}
grails schema-export -non-interactive file_name
{code}
fields.summary: Add option to the Grails Builder to allow "non-interactive" to don't be added to the grails command
When Maven runs release:perform goal, allow it to use the password defined in the Repository tab to commit data

fields.description:
1. Create Plan A using repo R, enable "shallow clones".
2. Run build A. Cache would be filled with two shallowest changesets.
3. Create Plan B using the same repo R, *disable* "shallow clones".
4. Run build B. Check contents of JOB working directory ({{git log}}).
4a. I expected full history will be available in the agent's working directory.
4b. Where Currently I've got only first changeset
4c. along with error message "could not read <hash>" <- due to fact, that JOB's .git directory doesn't contain _shallow_ file. But that's a minor issue here.
fields.summary: Git nonshallow plan should obtain full git history on local agent.
NPE during Maven detection if M2_HOME or MAVEN_HOME undefined

fields.description:
We would like to access the tags of a git repository during an CustomPreBuildAction.

Unfortunately the cloned repository within the Bamboo-Agent doesn't contain these tags. See the two screenshots:

In the remote-repository the history looks as follows:
!gitrepo-onhost.PNG!

The history of the repository within the bamboo-agent looks as follows:
!gitrepo-isinbambooagent.PNG!
fields.summary: Bamboo-Agent doesn't receive the tags of a cloned Git-Repository

fields.description:
Currently, Bamboo drops duplicate heartbeats.
This is not correct, these heartbeats should still update the last activity time for an agent, since it was definitely active at the point when it retried the transmission of heartbeat.
fields.summary: Retried heartbeats are discarded

fields.description:
When running clover with Ant, we need to tell ant the location of the clover.jar.  However on a remote agent, the clover.jar is on the server not on the agent.
# Clover code expects the jar to be either file: or jar:file: so will not recognise the location
# Even if it could recognise the location, I'm not sure we can make it available in ant.

Example Resource url: http://localhost:8085/bamboo/agentServer/GetResource.action?name=com/cenqua/clover/util/ClassPathUtil.class&fingerprint=8693082616509879305

The current workaround is to not use the automatic integration and do it manually. http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CLOVER/Clover-for-Ant
fields.summary: Automatic Clover Integration does not work for Ant + Remote Agents

fields.description:
Change set links point to the wrong URL if the Fisheye Web Repository is updated during the life time of a plan

How to reproduce:

# Create a plan with Subversion repository and Fisheye web repository which correctly correlates to the entered Subversion repository.
# Build the plan normally ensuring that changes occur and builds have change sets
# Modify the Subversion repository and the Fisheye web repository locations so that they are now pointing to completely different svnroot and project
# Run the plan as normal
# Old change sets will now point to the newly referenced Fisheye web repository, therefore having incorrect links

Note: Modifying the subversion repository in step 3 isn't really necessary other than to simulate that if an user updated the svn repository location they would update the Fisheye project, too.
fields.summary: Change sets link to incorrect locations when Fisheye Web Repository is modified
Edit artifact dependencies should show what job they come from.

fields.description:
Your going to need the variable name whilst in the edit view, (to use in e.g. your builder arguments), so we should show the variable next to the artifact dependencies e.g. like in the view config: https://skitch.com/brydiemccoy/rpjh5/artifacts-artifacts-lllll-build-configuration-atlassian-bambooooo

Also it helps with the "well i've created a definition, what do I do know" scenario.  

It also would be nice to give a bit more information as to what the variable name is/how to use it, but I don't really know how to do that. Maybe just add to the explanation text something like - "The variable name can be used elsewhere in you Job configuration to reference the location of the artifact"
fields.summary: Edit view of artifact dependencies should show variable name as well
